I4.1.name: Present Moats
I4.1.description: Count of moats with scores 9-10 (demonstrable competitive advantages)
I4.1.interpretation: No demonstrable moats yet—all defensibility is potential, not present. Expected for pre-launch venture.

I4.2.name: Potential Moats
I4.2.description: Count of moats with scores 5-8 (buildable competitive advantages)
I4.2.interpretation: Strong moat optionality with 5 potential moats (3 strong potential 7-8, 2 weak potential 5-6)

I4.3.name: Total Defensibility Score
I4.3.description: Count of moats with scores 7-10 (strong moats only)
I4.3.interpretation: Sustainable competitive advantage potential with 3 strong moats (Counter-Positioning 8, Speed 7, Scale Economies 7)

I4.4.name: Strongest Moat Score
I4.4.description: Highest individual moat score across all 8 types
I4.4.interpretation: Counter-Positioning moat (8/10) provides strategic differentiation—kiryana model forces incumbent dilemma

speed.rationale: Asset-light kiryana model enables faster iteration than dark-store competitors

process_power.rationale: Real-time inventory accuracy requires complex operational processes with kiryana partners

cornered_resources.rationale: Potential for exclusive kiryana partnerships and proprietary Karachi traffic data

switching_costs.rationale: Grocery delivery has inherently low switching costs—structurally weak category

counter_positioning.rationale: Kiryana model creates incumbent dilemma—copying would cannibalize dark store investments

brand.rationale: Grocery delivery is commodity category where functional attributes matter more than brand

network_effects.rationale: Weak network effects—single-player experience with no meaningful social/marketplace dynamics

scale_economies.rationale: Strong scale economy potential from fixed cost amortization and delivery density

decision_framework.rationale: 3 strong moats (7-10 scores) exceed ≥2 threshold; strongest moat 8/10 exceeds ≥6 threshold
execution_requirements: Prove 95%+ inventory accuracy with kiryana partners (Months 0-6)
Demonstrate superior unit economics vs. dark store model (Months 6-12)
Achieve 50,000 monthly orders to realize scale economies (Months 12-18)
